title.narrative: Fas II stöd till lokala fredsdialoger ILC i DRK
Phase II -Local peace dialogues by ILC in DRC 2020-2022

description.narrative:
Insatsen syftar till att stödja ILC (Initiative for Cohesive Leadership) i deras arbete med att skapa förutsättningar för fredsdialog och konfliktlösning/medling.
ILC är en franskregistrerad icke-statlig organisation med lång erfarenhet i DR Kongo inom området dialog och medling. ILCs metodologi bygger på att en fredlig lösning till konflikterna i DRK endast kan komma från kongoleserna själva.
Genom att anordna återkommande sammankomster under flertalet dagar med inflytelserika kongolesiska aktörer på alla nivåer och från olika samhällsskick arbetar ILC med att deltagarna ska fördjupa sin förståelse kring drivkrafterna för landets kriser.
Målet är att bygga motståndskraft hos lokala aktörer och invånare genom att fördjupa samhällsdynamiken i integreringsarbetet. ILC kommer att arbeta med försoning inom och mellan samhällen.
ILC kommer även att bygga på det momentum som skapades under 2019 när en decentraliserad mekanism för att avväpna, demobilisera och återintegrera soldater (DDR) började ta form i Nord och Sydkivu. Genom att bygga på existerande initiativ och ledarskap inom fredsprocesser så kommer ILC att arbeta med provinskommissionerna för att bidra till genomförandet av lokala DDR lösningar och återintegrering.
Vidare är ambitionen att deltagarna ska analysera eller nyansera sin övertygelse om att de inte är intressenter i de kriser som råder i landet (utökat ansvarstagande), samt analysera sin övertygelse om att det är upp till externa aktörer (internationella samfundet, grannländerna etc.) att lösa problemen. Målet är att uppnå en högre nivå av medvetande kring det personliga och lokala ansvaret i konflikter.
Ambassaden stödjer insatsen med 4 900 000 SEK under 2020-2022. Det svenska stödet är inte öronmärkt till vissa budgetutgifter utan utgör tillsammans med de andra givarnas bidrag stöd till projektet. Koordinering mellan ILC, Ambassaden och Schweiz sker löpande. Om flera givare bidrar i framtiden kommer koordineringen även att inkludera de länderna.

The initiative aims to support ILC (Initiative for Cohesive Leadership) in their work to create conditions for peace dialogue and conflict resolution / mediation.
ILC is a French registered non-governmental organization with long experience in DR Congo in the area of ??dialogue and mediation. ILC's methodology is based on the fact that a peaceful solution to the conflicts in the DRC can only come from the Congolese themselves.
By organizing recurring gatherings over several days with influential Congolese actors at all levels and from different backgrounds ILC is working to enable participants to deepen their understanding of the drivers of conflict.
The goal is to build resilience among local actors and communities by creating a more profound understanding of the existing social dynamics. ILC will work on reconciliation within and between communities.
ILC will build on the momentum created in 2019 when a decentralized Disarmament, Demobilization and Reintegration (DDR) mechanism began to take shape in North and South Kivu. Building on existing initiatives and leadership in peace processes ILC will work with the provincial commissions to strengthen implementation of local DDR solutions.
Furthermore, the ambition is for participants to nuance their firm belief that they are not stakeholders in the crises that prevail in the DRC (increased accountability), as well as revisit their conviction that it is up to external players (international community, neighboring countries, etc.) to solve the problems. The goal is to achieve a higher level of awareness of personal and local responsibility in conflicts.
The Embassy supports the project with 4 900 000 SEK during 2020-2022. The Swedish contribution is not earmarked to certain activities, it is to be seen as a contribution alongside other donors. Coordination between ILC, the Embassy and Switzerland takes place on a regular basis. If more donors contribute to the project in the future the coordination mechanism will be extended to include those countries.

The initiative aims to create conditions for peace dialogue and conflict resolution/mediation.
The main objective is to create a process and to build "spaces of trust" between key players in the region and in particular in Rwanda and the DRC. The expected results are as follows: - Cohesive leadership sessions result in a healthy debate between Congolese and Rwandan actors - ILC will demonstrate that areas of trust can be created between the two states irrespective of the complex history that exists. It is the responsibility of the participating actors to make something concrete and useful out of the 'spaces of trust' (for example: economic projects or implementation of Addis Ababa commitments). The second objective follows on from the Addis Ababa Framework Agreement and its chapter on regional commitments. The ILC will endeavor to bring influential players together around a table. The aim is to bring members of the National and Provincial Security Councils, diplomatic advisers, members of the Ministries of Foreign Affairs of Rwanda and DR Congo in particular together to test the potential of jointly analysing and discussing the causes of the mistrust which separates them.

description.narrative: The project description was originally focused on cross border diplomatic relation, to at least an aim to get closer to that as a result. The activities in 2020 were mainly focused on the conflict in South Kivu which is heavily influence by the cross border relationships. It is an important step towards creating a conducive environment for dialogue. The dialogues in Murhesa where organized in September 2020 and the discussions were attended by several armed groups, local representatives from the FARDC and the Ministry of Interior. The Ministry of defense sent a delegate to participate. This was one of the few times that so many different stakeholders participated in dialogue processes. This is one of few times that the central state is present in bringing cohesive leadership to the conflict areas of South Kivu. Note: In 2008, the Minister and the military hierarchy had avoided the Goma Conference, and above all, the “cohesive leadership” meeting following the signing of the Goma Act. During the dialogue, the Mai Mai and Banyamulenge self-defense groups were able to overcome their reciprocal issues and establish a relationship of mutual respect and empathy. This resulted in an open sharing of the location of their members and an incident verification matrix for the whole of South Kivu, which combines the contact details of FARDC officers and those of local officials of armed groups controlling a particular area. The matrix also identifies “areas not covered by respondents”, meaning that the leadership in these areas is disputed. The process demonstrated that a coalition of actors which recognize their interdependence van be a strong force in bringing about change. This is especially true in a country where community origins and history create deep rifts of mistrust and rivalry. Following the Murhesa dialogue ILC was invited to be included in the Head of State’s process on developing a new mechanism for community based DDR. While ILC led the initiative, the success came from a collaboration with Search for Common Ground, a local NGO called ADCI and the provincial commissions for DDRC. Unfortunately the governor of South Kivu did not participate but he did make contact at a later stage to understand the process and the results.
